title: 104_hr4111
content: The Act titled "Federal Law Enforcement Dependents Assistance Act of 1996" provides educational assistance to dependents of slain federal law enforcement officers. Amendments include the addition of "Subpart 2--Educational Assistance to Dependents of Civilian Federal Law Enforcement Officers Killed or Disabled in the Line of Duty." The "Federal Law Enforcement Dependents Assistance Act of 1996" now includes "Subpart 2--Educational Assistance to Dependents of Civilian Federal Law Enforcement Officers Killed or Disabled in the Line of Duty." This subpart aims to provide educational benefits to deserving dependents of officers who may not afford higher education due to the death or disability of an eligible officer. It also aims to help family members achieve the educational status they would have attained if the officer had not been killed or disabled in the line of duty. The "Federal Law Enforcement Dependents Assistance Act of 1996" provides financial assistance to dependents of eligible Federal law enforcement officers for education. Assistance is available to children or spouses of officers in case of death or disability. The benefits are computed based on set criteria and have a duration limit of forty-five months. Dependent children must be under 27 years old unless there are exceptional circumstances. Applications for assistance are subject to approval by the Attorney General. The Attorney General requires an application for assistance under the Federal Law Enforcement Dependents Assistance Act of 1996. Approval is granted unless the dependent is ineligible, the educational institution doesn't meet requirements, the program doesn't meet criteria, or the dependent is already qualified. Notification of approval or disapproval is provided to the applicant. The Attorney General notifies dependent applicants of approval or disapproval in writing for assistance under the Federal Law Enforcement Dependents Assistance Act of 1996. The Attorney General has the authority to create regulations for implementing a specific subpart. Assistance under this subpart may be discontinued if the recipient fails to maintain satisfactory progress according to the standards of the educational institution. SEC. 1216. SPECIAL RULE. Dependent of a Federal law enforcement officer killed in the line of duty on or after May 1, 1992, eligible for retroactive and prospective assistance under this subpart. Retroactive assistance can be provided for education pursued at an eligible institution, subject to limitations. Dependent may waive retroactive assistance and apply for prospective assistance. The term 'Attorney General' refers to the US Attorney General. 'Federal law enforcement officer' has the same meaning as in subpart 1. 'Program of education' includes coursework necessary for a specific educational or vocational goal. 'Eligible educational institution' is defined as an institution described in the Higher Education Act of 1965 and eligible for program participation. An eligible institution under the Higher Education Act of 1965, as in effect on the date of enactment, is eligible to participate in programs under title IV of the Act. Authorization of appropriations is granted for carrying out the specified subpart.
